newsitem.title: USA: BASEBALL-BERNIE WILLIAMS COMES BACK TO LIFE, AND SO DO YANKEES.
newsitem.headline: BASEBALL-BERNIE WILLIAMS COMES BACK TO LIFE, AND SO DO YANKEES.

text.p: Bernie Williams came back to life on Tuesday, and so did the road-warrior New York Yankees when his two-run homer in the eighth inning helped seal a 5-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves in Game 3 of the World Series.
Williams, the American League Championship Series Most Valuable Player who went hitless in losses in Games 1 and 2 of the World Series, drove in three runs and scored twice for the Yankees.
New York is trying to become just the third team ever to win a World Series after losing the first two games at home.
Yankee starter David Cone survived a tense pitchers' duel with Tom Glavine, leaving the game with the Yanks ahead 2-1 after six innings.
Glavine left after seven, but his reliever Greg McMichael let open the floodgates, allowing three runs, including Williams's home run.
The Yankees are now a perfect 6-0 on the road this post-season and need to win one of the next two games in Atlanta to guarantee a return of the best-of-seven series to New York.

The loss snapped a five-game win streak by the defending World Series champion Braves, who had won three in a row to take the National League Championship Series after trailing the St Louis Cardinals three games to one.
Cone, who got the win, allowed four hits, one run and four walks with three strikeouts.
Glavine, who pitched last year's Series clincher for the Braves, also allowed four hits, but two runs -- only one of them earned -- along with eight strikeouts and three walks.
McMichael allowed three runs on three hits without getting an out.
John Wetteland got the save, retiring three batters after a Derek Jeter error allowed the leadoff man on in the ninth.
